javaslang.algebra

Interface Monad3<T1,T2,T3,M extends HigherKinded3<?,?,?,M>>

  • Type Parameters:
    T1 - 1st component type of this monad
    T2 - 2nd component type of this monad
    T3 - 3rd component type of this monad
    M - placeholder for the type that implements this
    All Superinterfaces:
    Functor3<T1,T2,T3>, HigherKinded3<T1,T2,T3,M>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Tuple3

    public interface Monad3<T1,T2,T3,M extends HigherKinded3<?,?,?,M>>
extends Functor3<T1,T2,T3>, HigherKinded3<T1,T2,T3,M>
    Defines a Monad by generalizing the flatMap function.

    All instances of the Monad interface should obey the three control laws:

    • Left identity: unit(a).flatMap(f) ≡ f a
    • Right identity: m.flatMap(unit) ≡ m
    • Associativity: m.flatMap(f).flatMap(g) ≡ m.flatMap(x -> f.apply(x).flatMap(g)
    given
    • an object m of type HigherKinded3<T1, T2, T3, M>
    • an object a consisting of values of type T1 ✕ T2 ✕ T3
    • a constructor unit taking an a and producing an object of type M
    • a function f: T1 ✕ T2 ✕ T3 → M
    To read further about monads in Java please refer to What's Wrong in Java 8, Part IV: Monads.
    Since:
    1.1.0

      • flatMap

        <U1,U2,U3,MONAD extends HigherKinded3<U1,U2,U3,M>> Monad3<U1,U2,U3,M> flatMap(Function3<? super T1,? super T2,? super T3,MONAD> f)
        Returns the result of applying f to M's values of type T1,…,T3 and returns a new M with values of type U1,…,U3.
        Type Parameters:
        U1 - 1st component type of this monad
        U2 - 2nd component type of this monad
        U3 - 3rd component type of this monad
        MONAD - placeholder for the monad type of component types T1,…,T3 and container type M
        Parameters:
        f - a function that maps the monad values to a new monad instance
        Returns:
        a new monad instance of component types U1,…,U3 and container type M
